post_info.post_title: Quick question for the average scientist.

Iuris

Well, a non-scientist like me would start with the assumption that it's simply frozen condensed water from either the foodstuffs in the fridge or the air that enters the fridge whenever you open it and carries excess humidity compared to the standard temperatures in the fridge...
zachvac

Well, a non-scientist like me would start with the assumption that it's simply frozen condensed water from either the foodstuffs in the fridge or the air that enters the fridge whenever you open it and carries excess humidity compared to the standard temperatures in the fridge...

 
 That's what I would say, I don't know exactly.
omega

The peice of information that I... forgot to mention, is that there is no condensation envolved. You can open a freezer anywhere including a dry desert and you will find the "ice Crystals" if they are ice. The important point here is that there is no water on the outside of the freezer, no water in the inbetween state between water vapor and ice. Sorry for failing to mention this.
Kronus

The peice of information that I... forgot to mention, is that there is no condensation envolved. You can open a freezer anywhere including a dry desert and you will find the "ice Crystals" if they are ice. The important point here is that there is no water on the outside of the freezer, no water in the inbetween state between water vapor and ice. Sorry for failing to mention this.

 
 I don't see that as a problem. Water can go directly from vapor to solid without passing through a liquid state. I think it's called deposition. So those crystals are just plain ice.
